isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - IC BUS SERVICE MANUAL - DOORS AND ACCESSORIES - OUTWARD OPENING AND FORWARD FOLDING DOOR CONTROL LUBRICATION/ MAINTENANCE

svcproc.title: OUTWARD OPENING AND FORWARD FOLDING DOOR CONTROL LUBRICATION/ MAINTENANCE

svcprocinfo.para: Open and close the side emergency and/or rear emergency door. This will ensure penetration of lubricant in the required area. As part of general inspection, always open and close doors to inspect their operation. Always activate and de-activate the locking mechanism.

note.para: Instructional and warning decals must be re-installed on emergency doors, windows, etc. when repairs are performed.

svcsubproc.title: Inspection
svcsubproc.para: There are several points on the manual door operator and door itself that should be inspected, adjusted and lubricated for free and normal operation during routine maintenance (Every 30 days Recommended). The outward opening door hinge pins and nylon bearings should be inspected for wear. Nylon bushings and retainers at hinge pins should be replaced if they are worn or door is difficult to operate when disconnected from door control. The forward folding door hinge pin bushings and retainers at the top and bottom of the door should be inspected and replaced if door does not operate smoothly or is difficult when disconnected from manual door control. The roller bearing at the top of the door should be replaced if it is worn or will not turn easily.

Inspection of the manual door control requires removal of the right hand dash cover. First, remove the four screws that retain the black plastic door rod cover. Then, remove the buttons that cover screws on the right hand dash cover. Remove the screws that retain the right hand dash cover. Lift the dash cover and feed the door control rod past the clearance hole.

The manual door control has been tested to last the life of the vehicle. It requires regular lubrication with a graphite-based lubricant (Part# 407408R2) or equivalent and some adjustment may be required if it gets difficult to operate. If it is difficult to operate or stuck, first inspect the upper and lower nosing rubber; it should not drag or bind. If the nosing rubber is dragging or binding, it should be trimmed to allow the door to operate freely. Next, check the door control for any trash or loose components that may have fallen in the mechanism or slide. Take an air hose and blow this area clean.

warning.para: Compressed air can damage some sensitive components and turn loose debris into projectiles, so take the necessary safety precautions when using compressed air.

svcsubproc.para: Lubricate and adjust as described later in the manual.

svcsubproc.title: Adjustment

step1.para: Adjustment of Top Door Bar on Door Panels

If the door control becomes difficult to operate, first check for obstructions or loose components as described in the inspection process. Next, check the adjustment of the door control. There are three adjustments that can be made that affect the operation of the door control. They are: 1.) Nut adjustment of the pivot points on the operator itself, 2.) Adjustment of the door control rod that attaches to the door, and 3.) Adjustment of the bar that attaches the two door panels together at the top of the door. The first item that should be checked for out of adjustment operation is the bar at the top of the forward and rear door panels.

If this bar is out of adjustment, then the door control will be difficult to operate. Before adjusting this bar, remove the door control rod from the forward door panel. Remove the keeper ring from the pin that attaches the rod clevis to the door bracket.

Pull rod away from door. Door panels should open and close easily by hand. If they do not, then rod at the top of the door requires adjustment. On doors with four piece glass, loosen bolts at top of door that attach bar brackets to door.

caution.para: Caution should be taken when manually operating the doors with the rod detached; a detached rod can damage windows.

step1.para: To adjust bar, pull doors completely closed and allow bar to slide into proper position. With doors closed, tighten one fastener on each bracket, making sure the brackets are straight and level. Open and close doors a couple of times to ensure that doors operate smoothly without binding. If doors bind or resist, repeat procedure and re-adjust brackets. If doors operate smoothly, tighten remaining fasteners. Spray a high quality graphite-based lubricant (Part# 407408R2) or equivalent onto bar pin connections at top of doors. Open and close doors several times to work in lubricant. Re-attach door control rod, pin and keeper to door bracket. Operate door control several times and determine if operation efforts are reduced. If door control is still difficult to operate, then door control rod may need adjustment.

If door does not fully open or close, is difficult to open or close, or if door is difficult to latch, then door control rod yoke may need adjustment. Use the following logic to determine how to adjust rod yoke.

entry.para: Door control is hard to latch
Yoke needs to be extended on control rod or turned counter-clockwise
Door is difficult to close
Yoke needs to be extended on control rod or turned counter-clockwise
Doors do not close all the way
Yoke needs to be brought into rod or turned clockwise
Doors do not open all the way
Yoke needs to be extended or turned counter-clockwise
Door control lock open position is difficult
Yoke needs to be brought into rod or turned clockwise
Door control lock open position is too weak
Yoke needs to be extended or turned counter-clockwise

step1.para: The door control and door operation is sensitive to adjustment of the door rod yoke. Make small adjustments and try door control for proper operation. Correct adjustment of the door control will allow the door to operate properly and easily.

Prior to removal of the rod yoke from the door bracket, loosen the 5/8" hex nut next to the door rod yoke. To adjust the door control rod yoke, remove the retainer on the bottom of the pin that attaches the rod yoke to the door bracket. Remove the pin from the yoke and door control bracket. Rotate the yoke either extending it or decreasing the length according to need. Make adjustments one turn at a time, then re-attach rod yoke to door bracket. Do not install retainer yet.

caution.para: Caution should be taken when manually operating the doors with the rod detached; a detached rod can damage windows.

step1.para: Operate the door control and check operation. Once final adjustment has been made, install pin retainer. Tighten 5/8" diameter yoke retaining nut. Do not over-tighten. Ensure that when tightening yoke nut that the yoke is parallel to the door control end to prevent binding.
To make adjustments to the door control mechanism the dash cover will have to be removed. Remove four screws retaining black door rod cover from right hand dash cover.

Remove retaining ring on pin that attaches end of door control rod to door control bracket. Remove pin and disconnect rod from door control bracket. Remove buttons on front of right hand dash and remove screws retaining dash. Feed door control rod past dash and lift dash off of bus.

Door control should operate easily without door control rod attached to door. If door control mechanism feels stiff or hard to operate, then the pivot bolts and nuts on door control may need to be adjusted.

There are three fasteners on the pivot triangle which require periodic adjustment. First, identify the fastener that fits into the slot in the triangle. This fastener attaches the control arm to the triangle. Initially, tighten the bolt to 15 ft-lbs., then back off the nut half turn.

The second fastener is the pivot stud for the door control rod. Loosen and torque the nut to 15 ft-lbs., then back off the nut ¼ turn. The door control rod should pivot easily on the stud without resistance. If some resistance is felt, back off the nut slightly until the door control rod pivots easily.

The third fastener is the pivot bolt for the triangle. This fastener is retained with a ¼" diameter lock screw. Loosen the lock screw with a cross-head screwdriver. Loosen the ½" diameter bolt, then torque to 25 ft-lbs. Back off this nut ¼ turn. Tighten ¼" diameter lock screw.

Operate the door control a couple of times while holding the door control rod. It should operate smoothly and easily at about 3-1/2 lbs. of effort. If it does not, slightly loosen the pivot bolt and slide nut until the door control operates easily. Remember that the lock screw on the triangle pivot bolt will have to be loosened and re-tightened every time you adjust the pivot bolt.

Install the door control rod yoke on the door bracket with pin and retainer. Install the right hand dash cover back onto the dash console with the screws and buttons that were removed. Install the black plastic door control rod cover onto the dash. Adjustment and installation is complete. If the door control has been in service for one year, then it should be lubricated. (See lubrication and maintenance section.)

svcsubproc.para: If the forward folding door does not open or close all the way or the door control is difficult to latch, then the door control rod may need adjustment. Use the following logic to determine how to adjust the door control rod on the forward folding door.

entry.para: Door control is difficult to latch
Decrease rod length by turning door control rod yoke inward
Door is difficult to close against rubber seals
Decrease length of door control rod by turning yoke inward
Door does not open all the way or does not seal adequately against rubber seals
Increase door control rod length by extending yoke

svcsubproc.para: To adjust the door control rod, loosen the 5/8" diameter hex nut securing the yoke that is attached to the door control bracket. Remove the retaining ring at the bottom of the pin. Remove the pin that attaches the rod yoke to the door control bracket. Rotating the yoke either clockwise or counter-clockwise changes the rod length and adjustment. Rotating the yoke clockwise decreases the length of the rod. Rotating counter-clockwise extends the length of the rod.

Make adjustments in one turn intervals, re-install the pin into the yoke and door bracket and check the operation of the door control. Once satisfactory adjustments have been made, re-install retainer ring onto pin and tighten yoke retaining nut. When tightening yoke retaining nut, ensure that rod end that is attached to door control is not being rotated against pivot stud and binding. Yoke retaining nut should not be over-tightened. Yoke should be parallel with door control bracket.
To adjust the door control mechanism for a forward folding door follow the same procedure as outline for the outward opening door.

A switch attached to the door control activates the warning lights. If the warning lights do not operate properly when the door control is operated, the warning light switch may need to be replaced or adjusted. To adjust the warning light switch, the right hand dash cover must be removed. Remove the four screws retaining the black plastic cover around the door control rod. Remove the buttons and the cross-head screws retaining the right hand dash cover. Remove the right hand dash cover and feed the dash past the door control rod. The switch is located at the opposite end of the door control as the handle. With the door control in the full closed position, the button of the switch should be exposed 1/16".

Once the switch is adjusted, open and close the door control to ensure proper operation of the warning lights. If the warning lights still do not operate properly or the switch will not remain adjusted, replace warning light switch. Replace dash cover and door control rod cover plate in reverse order it was removed.

svcsubproc.title: Lubrication and Maintenance

para.title: Outward Opening and Forward Folding Doors

svcsubproc.para: Manual door control and doors should be lubricated to ensure proper operation. If doors or door controls are being adjusted, they should be lubricated during this process. Door controls and doors should be lubricated during regular maintenance intervals (Every 30 days Recommended) of the bus.

The door hinge pins may be lubricated by spraying a high quality graphite-based lubricant (Part# 407408R2) or equivalent on these areas. This may also be done on the door control rod hinge-pin. Wipe off any excess lubricant. Open and close door several times to work in lubricant.

Forward folding doors should also be lubricated regularly with a high quality graphite-based lubricant to ensure proper operation. Forward folding doors are more susceptible to wear than outward opening doors. Spray lubricant on top and bottom hinge points of forward leaf of door. Spray lubricant on piano type hinge between forward and rear door leafs. Also, spray lubricant on roller bearing in track at top of door. Wipe off any excess lubricant. Open and close doors several times to work in the lubricant.

Door control should be lubricated during the regular maintenance schedule (Every 30 days Recommended) or if door control becomes difficult to operate. To lubricate door control, the right hand dash cover must be removed. First, remove four screws retaining black plastic door rod cover. Next, remove buttons and cross-head screws retaining dash cover on bus. Then, lift off dash cover and feed over door control rod.
There are six areas that require lubrication on the linear stroke door control.

item.para: Slide mounted on door control base.
Nylon wear pad between control arm and base-plate.
Nylon wear pad between pivot triangle and control arm.
Sliding point at slot in pivot triangle.
Pivot stud at triangle base-plate attachment.

svcsubproc.para: Apply a high quality graphite-based lubricant (Part# 407408R2) or equivalent to the nylon wear pad between control arm and base-plate, the nylon wear pad between pivot triangle and control arm, and to the slot in pivot triangle. Spray high quality graphite-based lubricant on triangle pivot bolt, rod pivot stud, and operator slide. Open and close doors several times to work in the lubricant. If adjustments are necessary, see previous sections on adjustment of door control and doors. Re-install dash cover door rod cover in reverse order of removal.

entry.para: Problem
Remedy
1. Door control is hard to operate.
1A. Determine if door bar on top of door panels is adjusted properly.
1B. Determine if door rod is adjusted properly. See section on door rod adjustment.
1C. Door control and doors need lubrication. See section on door and door control lubrication.
2. Door control is difficult to latch.
2A. Door control rod requires adjustment. See section on door control rod adjustment.
3. Doors do not close all the way.
3A. Door control rod requires adjustment. See section on door control rod adjustment.
4. Doors do not open all the way.
4A. Door control rod requires adjustment. See section on door control rod adjustment.
5. Door control break- over to hold door in open position is too hard.
5A. Door control rod requires adjustment. See section on door control rod adjustment.
6. Door control break-over is too weak. No detent in door control when opening to full open position.
6A. Door control rod requires adjustment. See section on door control rod adjustment.
7. Door control is stuck. Won't operate.

7A. Remove dash cover from dash. Disconnect door control rod from door as described in instructions. Determine if door control is stuck or door is stuck. If door is stuck, investigate door pins and center hinge for proper operation. Replace parts if necessary.
7B. If door is OK. Investigate door slide, triangle and control arm. Determine if there are any loose parts or components in mechanism preventing it from working.
7C. Investigate door control for any worn or damaged parts. Replace damaged or worn parts.
8. Warning lights don't operate properly.
8A. Warning light switch on door control requires adjustment. If switch cannot be adjusted or will not stay adjusted, replace switch. See section on door control switch adjustment.
